Yes; off at a tangent here (and not for the first time): but here's a few other general observations, if permitted.
 
 The problem of low standards in education is not confined to science subjects, or to America. For instance, I've noted the exasperation of former colleagues giving "crash" courses in remedial mathematics to students who are supposed to be registered for engineering degrees. In my own field of "expertise" which was (or, I like to believe, still is) the teaching of English, it has been apparent for some years that the university student who can write a logically constructed paragraph without a litter of mistakes in spelling, grammar, and punctuation, is becoming a rarity.
 
 Scientific ignorance, semi-literacy, innumeracy, and so on, seem to be the products of an educational "philosophy" that has undermined standards to a point where, apart from cultural anxieties, even a mere "philistine" concern for the future of our competitive edge is justified.
 
 The blame for this problem starts, I conjecture, at primary and secondary school level. Children are no longer exposed to the rigour and discipline of a subject orientated curriculum and expected to master certain basic skills and to acquire a body of knowledge, etc. Instead a "child-centred" approach has introduced talk about "feelings" and "fun" in place of the serious application required to surmount the admitted difficulties of learning anything worthwhile. Perhaps I exaggerate a little here, but not much.
 
 There is no sign at present (at least here in the UK) of any significant change in this state of educational affairs. Dumbing down shows few signs of being eliminated from schools: sentimental humbug about promoting "self esteem" as an educational end - perhaps the educational end - continues to produce very poorly prepared and even deeply ignorant applicants for places at universities. It is probable that the study of the sciences suffers most from this lack of adequate primary education - the objectivity of science offers far less scope for the "waffle" that is tolerated by the elasticity of arts subjects.
 
 Excuse the "scare quotes" all over the place, but my sense of irony often gets in the way of a dispassionate discourse.
